results.title: A Track winding back
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
This documentary is based on a true story written by school teacher Carolyn Landon about bushman, Daryl Tonkin and his life and memories of Jackson’s Track in West Gippsland, Victoria. It is a story of love and tragedy, of an Aboriginal community living and working harmoniously with white people in the timber industry in the forest area of Jackson’s Track established by Daryl and his brother Harry during the 1930s. It tells of Daryl’s feud with his family when he decided to live with an Aboriginal woman, the dramatic kidnapping of this woman by his brother, Daryl’s life with the Aboriginal community and the eventual bull-dozing of the camp in the 1960s to appease local Christian groups resulting in the break-up and dispersal of the almost 100 people living at the camp. Daryl talks of himself as being at one with the Aboriginal way of life, a true bushman, who saw his life neither primitive nor of poverty and hardship, but as being his preferred way of life. Includes interviews with two of his nine children, re-enactments, stills and archival footage, and excerpts from the film “Rose against the odds”. Contains some b&w images.

results.title: Zimbabwe, Botswana & Namibia
results.creator_credit: Stephen Lennhoff, Phil Frank and Pilot Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lonely planet: the experience”.
Join Andrew Daddo as he explores Zimbabwe, Botswana and Namibia in another ‘Lonely Planet’ travel video. Bungee jump above the Zambezi river, snack on the delicacy of boiled worms, come face to face with a pride of lions, canoe through crocodile infested waters and ride in a dunebuggy over the Namibia desert.

results.title: The Cape crusade
results.creator_credit: Helen Grasswill and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
Noel Pearson, Aboriginal lawyer and Cape York adviser, and his brother Gerhardt Pearson, Cape York leader, together and along with several key business people, philanthropists and the corporate world are attempting to change the social disintegration within the Cape York Aboriginal communities. This program explores the establishment of the Indigenous Enterprise Partnerships, a concept and strategy initiated by Noel Pearson, comprising of four private business entities - Westpac, Myer Foundation, Boston Consultancy and Bodyshop - and other leaders in the business world, along with Aboriginal leaders to provide employment and education to the remote indigenous communities and instigate social change especially amongst the younger generation. Disillusioned with Government bureaucracy and the welfare system, Noel and Gerhardt are committed to change, believing that to overcome the unemployment, alcoholism, gambling, illicit drug use, family violence and child abuse, change has to come from within the Aboriginal community itself. “Australian story” presents some of the early successes resulting from the partnership and includes interviews with Ann Sherry (Westpac), Colin Carter (Boston Consultancy), Noel Pearson and Gerhardt Pearson. Hosted by Caroline Jones.

results.title: Australian story
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
From the ABC television series “Australian Story” comes this compilation of five moving portraits of five very different Australians. Common to all five though is that they are battlers in their own way, overcoming adversity and hardship to live life as best they can. “The Big ‘A’” is about former Prime Minister’s wife Hazel Hawke speaking about her struggle with Alzheimer’s disease. “A Man for all seasons” is the story of revered rugby coach Wayne Bennett. “Boots and all” is about the discovery of a wonderful opera singer in a local shoe-repair shop - Peter Brocklehurst. “About a boy” is the story of young cricket enthusiast Dan Halloran, who grew up with his mother having a mental illness. “On the mountain top” is about Victoria Friend and her survival of a plane crash in remote country Australia.

results.title: The Caribou hunters
results.creator_credit: Stephen Greenless, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The Cree and Chippewa Indians of northern Manitoba lead a nomadic life as they roam the northern stretches of forest and tundra in search of the caribou that is their main source of food. The camera follows a group of Indian hunters with their dog teams as they move with the herds and at the same time trap the smaller animals of the forest and streams. Their focal point is the Hudson’s Bay Company trading post, where they bring their furs to exchange for the few essentials of their hardy existence. We also see their camp life, and examples of their colorful handicrafts. (Award: Dusseldorf)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stephen Greenless, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: To hell and back. Dr. Bavandra interview.
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
This video contains two programs from the Four Corners series. 1. To hell and back - schizophrenics talk about what it means to be a schizophrenic attempting to live in society. Treatment with drugs is discussed and the need for support from others is stressed. 2. Dr. Bavandra interview - Dr. Timotei Bavandra is interviewed about the coup in Fiji.

results.title: Deadly chemistry
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
This video deals with the public health and safety risks associated with fires of toxic chemicals. In Australia a number of large storage sites for such chemicals are located close to populous suburban areas. Presented by Andrew Olle.

results.title: 1918 Remembered
results.creator_credit: Victoria Pitt, ABC-TV (Australia) and Roadshow Entertainment
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
From the ABC series “Four Corners” comes reporter Chris Masters visit to the western Front of the First World war to commemorate the 80th anniversary of the armistice. He explores the turbulent relationship between Australia and our main ally, the British. Never before seen footage from some of the war’s most famous battles, as well as the diggers own uncensored accounts help us to relive their journey and remember an era that shaped our future.

results.title: The Timber mafia [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Janine Cohen, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and TVE International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
A revealing profile on the illegal timber trade which is highly organised and operating on an international level involving several source countries throughout Asia, Africa and South America. Focusing on Indonesia, a major source country where it is thought up to 70% of all logging is illegal, reporter Stephen McDonell, with the support of Faith Doherty from the London-based Environmental Investigation Agency, attempts to seek out exactly how and where this illegal timber finally ends up. Starting in Kalimantan province, Indonesia, their investigative journey follows the trail from the illegally harvested timber in the rain forest national parks to neighbouring countries where the timber is “laundered” making it almost impossible to prove its origins. The wood is then shipped off to ports throughout Europe, Australia, China and Japan with no questions asked by the importers. This illegal industry which is destroying the environment and threatening the habitat of endangered animals and biodiversity of rain forests is also a danger to both those involved and those who dare to resist or prevent the warlords and timber barons from carrying out their business. Violence and corruption exists everywhere, even within governments and whilst trading regulations and jurisdictions remain complex and uncoordinated, the “timber mafia” will continue to rape the globe’s rain forests and devastate the ecosystems which inhabit these amazing ancient forests.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Janine Cohen, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and TVE International
